result.markdown:
---
title: "MATH167R: Simulation based inference"
author: "Peter Gao"
format: 
  revealjs:
    theme: [./slides.scss, ../theme.scss]
editor: visual
---


## Overview of today

-   Sampling distributions
-   Bootstrap distributions

## Sampling distributions

Without explicitly saying so, we have been simulating sampling distributions during our simulations.

Recall: A sampling distribution is the probability distribution of a sample-based statistic.

Example: If $X_1,\ldots, X_{100}$ are iid random variables with variance $1$, what is the distribution of the sample mean $\overline{X}$?

## Simulating a sampling distribution

Example simulation: Suppose $X_1,\ldots, X_{100}\sim N(0,1)$.


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/sample_mean_ad3312649e32b269513be4a8dad0343f'}

```{.r .cell-code}
set.seed(123)
Xbar <- replicate(10000, mean(rnorm(100)))
hist(Xbar, main = "Sampling distribution of mean of 100 N(0, 1) variables")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/sample_mean-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Simulating a sampling distribution

What if $X_1,\ldots, X_{100}\sim \mathrm{Exp}(1)$?


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/sample_mean_exp_34fb687a17c84389da9102078c6c0ea2'}

```{.r .cell-code}
set.seed(123)
Xbar <- replicate(10000, mean(rexp(100, rate = 1)))
hist(Xbar, main = "Sampling distribution of mean of 100 Exponential(1) variables")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/sample_mean_exp-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Simulating a sampling distribution

What if $X_1,\ldots, X_{100}\sim \mathrm{Poisson}(1)$?


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/sample_mean_pois_f39cf15cde015633c85e466e36048c26'}

```{.r .cell-code}
set.seed(123)
Xbar <- replicate(10000, mean(rpois(100, lambda = 1)))
hist(Xbar, main = "Sampling distribution of mean of 100 Poisson(1) variables")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/sample_mean_pois-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Simulating a sampling distribution

By the central limit theorem, all of these sampling distributions are asymptotically Gaussian with variance 1/100 (though the mean values differ between the three). Since $n=100$ is fairly large (for these examples), all of the previous examples are close to Gaussian.

What about if $n$ is smaller? Or if we consider other distributions?

Simulation is a powerful strategy for testing out methods:

-   Suppose you wish to know... is $n$ large?
-   Create a simulation that generates data that looks like your real world data.
-   Evaluate whether the results are reasonable/accurate using simulated data.

## Smaller sample sizes


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/smaller_sample_341da4284cd28aa3c8c72b1e6f920170'}

```{.r .cell-code}
set.seed(123)
Xbar_normal <- replicate(10000, mean(rnorm(10)))
Xbar_exp <- replicate(10000, mean(rexp(10, rate = 1)))
Xbar_poisson <- replicate(10000, mean(rpois(10, lambda = 1)))
par(mfrow = c(1, 3))
hist(Xbar_normal, main = "N(0, 1)")
hist(Xbar_exp, main = "Exp(1)")
hist(Xbar_poisson, main = "Poisson(1)")
```
:::


## Smaller sample sizes


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/smaller_sample2_cffe7e8e3206aa8145f46cc463415edb'}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/smaller_sample2-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Other statistics

What if we want the sampling distribution of the maximum? For each of these population models, the sampling distribution of the maximum is different.


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/max_sampling_dist_76c2db9f957c3055e659bad92ab18968'}

```{.r .cell-code}
set.seed(123)
Xmax_normal <- replicate(10000, max(rnorm(10)))
Xmax_exp <- replicate(10000, max(rexp(10, rate = 1)))
Xmax_poisson <- replicate(10000, max(rpois(10, lambda = 1)))
par(mfrow = c(1, 3))
hist(Xmax_normal, main = "N(0, 1)")
hist(Xmax_exp, main = "Exp(1)")
hist(Xmax_poisson, main = "Poisson(1)")
```
:::


## Other statistics

What if we want the sampling distribution of the maximum? For each of these population models, the sampling distribution of the maximum is different.


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/max_sampling_dist2_9a7b41002439f72a796fcc17c1788c10'}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/max_sampling_dist2-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Transformations

We can easily simulate sampling distributions for statistics summarizing the distribution of random variables that are defined as transformations of other random variables.


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/mean_transformed_9735cdcfbc7d07668c389a116c2645c0'}

```{.r .cell-code}
set.seed(123)
Xbar_normal <- replicate(10000, mean(rnorm(10) ^ 2))
Xbar_exp <- replicate(10000, mean(rexp(10, rate = 1) ^ 2))
Xbar_poisson <- replicate(10000, mean(rpois(10, lambda = 1) ^ 2))
par(mfrow = c(1, 3))
hist(Xbar_normal, main = "N(0, 1) squared")
hist(Xbar_exp, main = "Exp(1) squared")
hist(Xbar_poisson, main = "Poisson(1) squared")
```
:::


## Transformations

We can easily simulate sampling distributions for statistics summarizing the distribution of random variables that are defined as transformations of other random variables.


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/mean_transformed2_45dc3c8945060e2b1c26c6a7081f221b'}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/mean_transformed2-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Exercise

-   Write code to create a histogram of the sampling distribution of the sample mean $\overline{Y}$ of $Y_1,\ldots, Y_{10}$ where $Y_i=\sin(X_i)$ and $X_1,\ldots, X_{10}$ are iid Uniform(0, 1) random variables.

## Resampling methods

The previous simulations are all based on parametric models (normal, exponential, Poisson). However, we can also simulate sampling distributions without parametric assumptions on the data generating mechanism.

## Estimating the age of US pennies

Suppose we want to estimate the average age of US pennies. We can't observe every single penny---so what if we take a sample of 50 pennies?

![](images/pennies.png)

Based on an example from [ModernDive](https://moderndive.com/8-confidence-intervals.html).


## Estimating the age of US pennies

The `moderndive` package contains data on a sample of 50 pennies in the `pennies_sample` data frame.


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_1_552ae43730699cfeaf9d8df99724392f'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(moderndive)
data(pennies_sample)
head(pennies_sample)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 6 × 2
     ID  year
  <int> <dbl>
1     1  2002
2     2  1986
3     3  2017
4     4  1988
5     5  2008
6     6  1983
```
:::
:::


## Estimating the age of US pennies

The `moderndive` package contains data on a sample of 50 pennies in the `pennies_sample` data frame.


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
ggplot(pennies_sample, aes(x = year)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 10, color = "white") +
  theme_minimal()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/pennies_2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%}
:::
:::



## Estimating the age of US pennies

Based on this sample, we can compute the sample mean:


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_3_721691b5ad457cc7fbf2912ff8066f7c'}

```{.r .cell-code}
x_bar <- pennies_sample |>
  summarize(mean_year = mean(year))
x_bar
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_year
      <dbl>
1     1995.
```
:::
:::


## Resampling the pennies

Imagine we put our 50 pennies in a bag and draw a **new** sample of 50 pennies by sampling with replacement. This is called **resampling with replacement.**


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_4_545dd62000056a0e7e56776a5ee7f26d'}

```{.r .cell-code}
set.seed(327)
pennies_resample <-
  data.frame(year = sample(pennies$year, 50, replace = T))
head(pennies_resample)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  year
1 1973
2 1977
3 1976
4 2004
5 1981
6 2000
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
pennies_resample %>% 
  summarize(mean_year = mean(year))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  mean_year
1   1987.58
```
:::
:::



## Resampling the pennies {.smaller}

Imagine we put our 50 pennies in a bag and draw a **new** sample of 50 pennies by sampling with replacement. This is called **resampling with replacement.**


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_5_a252ab911fcd5649cd3697cf740713b6'}

```{.r .cell-code}
pennies_combined <- 
  bind_rows(pennies_sample |> mutate(title = "Original sample"),
            pennies_resample |> mutate(title = "Resample"))
ggplot(pennies_combined, aes(x = year)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 10, color = "white") +
  facet_wrap(~title) + 
  theme_minimal()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/pennies_5-1.png){fig-align='center' width=100%}
:::
:::


## Resampling the pennies

Note that our resample is not the same as drawing a new sample from the population. However, we can still learn about the **sampling variability** of the sample mean. Suppose we repeat this process many times.


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_6_e86185079b6f97f30ec424361c94deda'}

```{.r .cell-code}
head(pennies_resamples)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 6 × 3
# Groups:   name [1]
  replicate name     year
      <int> <chr>   <dbl>
1         1 Arianna  1988
2         1 Arianna  2002
3         1 Arianna  2015
4         1 Arianna  1998
5         1 Arianna  1979
6         1 Arianna  1971
```
:::
:::


## Resampling the pennies

We can compute each resample mean:


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_7_060c53570506f6ebe54b3d0d8c8a460f'}

```{.r .cell-code}
resampled_means <- pennies_resamples |>
  group_by(name) |>
  summarize(mean_year = mean(year))
head(resampled_means)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 6 × 2
  name      mean_year
  <chr>         <dbl>
1 Arianna       1992.
2 Artemis       1996.
3 Bea           1996.
4 Camryn        1997.
5 Cassandra     1991.
6 Cindy         1995.
```
:::
:::


## Resampling the pennies

We can compute each resample mean:


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_8_7404d1fbfae33e5736823d444b0d33e9'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(resampled_means, aes(x = mean_year)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 1, color = "white", boundary = 1990) +
  labs(x = "Sampled mean year") +
  theme_minimal()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/pennies_8-1.png){fig-align='center' width=100%}
:::
:::



## Resampling the pennies 1000 times

Using simulation, we can repeat this process virtually 1000 times:


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_9_f352edd547e23176e280689cfd4794be'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Repeat resampling 1000 times
virtual_resamples <- pennies_sample |>
  rep_sample_n(size = 50, replace = TRUE, reps = 1000)

# Compute 1000 sample means
virtual_resampled_means <- virtual_resamples |>
  group_by(replicate) |>
  summarize(mean_year = mean(year))
```
:::


## Resampling the pennies 1000 times

Using simulation, we can repeat this process virtually 1000 times:


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_10_301f5f2e52da7782fef0a292bc88055a'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(virtual_resampled_means, aes(x = mean_year)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 1, color = "white", boundary = 1990) +
  labs(x = "sample mean") +
  theme_minimal()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/pennies_10-1.png){fig-align='center' width=100%}
:::
:::


## Resampling the pennies 1000 times

Note that our resampled means are centered around our original sample mean. This means that resampling doesn't tell us about how far off our particular sample is--only about the variability of the observed values.


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_11_ef9208b9f258785de3c564b5175cd2a7'}

```{.r .cell-code}
virtual_resampled_means |>
  summarize(mean_of_means = mean(mean_year))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_of_means
          <dbl>
1         1995.
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(pennies_sample$year)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 1995.44
```
:::
:::


## Resampling confidence intervals {.smaller}

We can obtain a confidence interval based on our resample means:


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_12_2fbc8a6e6a294a5abd4ed98a90234eac'}

```{.r .cell-code}
quantile(virtual_resampled_means$mean_year, c(.025, .975))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
    2.5%    97.5% 
1991.358 1999.441 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(virtual_resampled_means, aes(x = mean_year)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 1, color = "white", boundary = 1990) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = quantile(virtual_resampled_means$mean_year, c(.025, .975)), 
             color = 'red') +
  labs(x = "sample mean") +
  theme_minimal()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/pennies_12-1.png){fig-align='center' width=100%}
:::
:::


## Resampling confidence intervals

Compare with a normal sampling distribution based confidence interval:


::: {.cell layout-align="center" hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/pennies_113_2b16abbda35f522a26ebed02e902ee9d'}

```{.r .cell-code}
virtual_resampled_means |>
  summarize(lower = mean(mean_year) - 1.96 * sd(mean_year),
            upper = mean(mean_year) + 1.96 * sd(mean_year))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 1 × 2
  lower upper
  <dbl> <dbl>
1 1991. 2000.
```
:::
:::



## Resampling methods

Suppose we know $X_1,\ldots, X_{20}\sim \mathrm{Exp}(1)$. The sampling distribution of the sample mean can be simulated as follows:


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/exp_samp_dist_4e55ee7ec70e7e3acc44ed910c30792c'}

```{.r .cell-code}
set.seed(123)
Xbar_exp <- replicate(10000, mean(rexp(20, rate = 1)))
hist(Xbar_exp)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/exp_samp_dist-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Resampling methods

What if we observe $X_1,\ldots, X_{20}$, but we don't know that $X_i$ is exponentially distributed? We could just try the normal approximation to approximate the sampling distribution.


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/exp_samp_dist_2_0c89708bd2b14bc99e1cfaa2ffc02a85'}

```{.r .cell-code}
X <- rexp(20, rate = 1)
x_axis <- seq(0, 3, length.out = 1000)

# plot "true" simulated sampling distribution
hist(Xbar_exp, freq = F, ylim = c(0, 3))

# plot normal theory
lines(x_axis, dnorm(x_axis, mean = mean(X), sd = sd(X) / sqrt(20)), col = 'red')
```
:::


## Resampling methods


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/exp_samp_dist_22_b88d48d6bc8d9458eb8fb7fe3a7bf0c2'}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/exp_samp_dist_22-1.png){width=480}
:::
:::


## Bootstrap samples

Bootstrapping is a resampling method that uses random samples with replacement from the sample data to approximate the sampling distribution of sample-based statistics.


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/exp_samp_dist_3_b2350d1d481e0495aecf642e101cba07'}

```{.r .cell-code}
print(sort(X))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
 [1] 0.00816693 0.06263315 0.11949335 0.12600941 0.14474580 0.14660666
 [7] 0.15582213 0.17485277 0.23514296 0.35492087 0.48980207 0.52215538
[13] 0.72200938 1.27034542 1.56551624 1.74866229 1.82459209 1.84311722
[19] 2.14225230 2.24995288
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# sample with replacement from X
X_resample <- sample(X, size = 20, replace = TRUE)
print(sort(X_resample))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
 [1] 0.06263315 0.11949335 0.11949335 0.11949335 0.11949335 0.12600941
 [7] 0.14474580 0.14474580 0.15582213 0.15582213 0.17485277 0.35492087
[13] 0.35492087 0.48980207 0.72200938 0.72200938 1.56551624 2.14225230
[19] 2.24995288 2.24995288
```
:::
:::


## Bootstrap samples

We can repeatedly resample from $X$, then compute the resample sample means and plot the distribution:


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/exp_samp_dist_4_7d0ded409fd1da8f97679cdf41f9ddad'}

```{.r .cell-code}
bootstrap_Xbar <- replicate(10000, mean(sample(X, size = 20, replace = TRUE)))
hist(bootstrap_Xbar - mean(X) + 1)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/exp_samp_dist_4-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Bootstrap samples

We can compare the bootstrap sampling distributions and true sampling distributions for $\overline{X}-E(\overline{X})$.


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/exp_samp_dist_5_c00e11897869b58847bbf7f3dc69ed1a'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggplot2)
plot_dat <-
  data.frame(Xbar = c(Xbar_exp - 1, bootstrap_Xbar - mean(X)),
             source = rep(c("Parametric (Exp)", "Bootstrap"), each = 10000))
ggplot(plot_dat, aes(x = Xbar, color = source)) +
  geom_density() +
  geom_function(fun = dnorm, 
                args = list(mean = 0, sd = 1 / sqrt(20)),
                aes(color = "Parametric (Normal)")) +
  xlab("Xbar - E(Xbar)")
```
:::


## Bootstrap samples

We can compare the bootstrap sampling distributions and true sampling distributions for $\overline{X}-E(\overline{X})$.


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/exp_samp_dist_52_ef5fb37f6a02f99e9dc9d4f25244c0c6'}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](19_simulation-based-inference_files/figure-revealjs/exp_samp_dist_52-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Bootstrap confidence intervals

We can take appropriate quantiles of the bootstrap samples to construct a bootstrap confidence interval using the `quantile()` function:


::: {.cell hash='19_simulation-based-inference_cache/revealjs/exp_samp_dist_6_15a94a72faf27caa3d5f92afb5da315d'}

```{.r .cell-code}
quantile(bootstrap_Xbar, probs = c(.025, .975))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
    2.5%    97.5% 
0.467759 1.157051 
```
:::
:::


## Why bootstrap?

In this case, inference based on bootstrapping does not seem better than the normal approximation based on the central limit theorem.

However, for many cases, we may not have a simple parametric approximation to the true sampling distribution. For example, suppose we wish to compute the sampling distribution of the sample median.

Note however that the bootstrap may not work well for all statistics, such as the minimum (why not?).

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
